A letter from Common Cause, Democracy 21 and other good government groups said the public financing system has served the country and presidential candidates of both parties well for most of its 35-year existence and the system only began to decline when campaign costs outstripped the public financing provided to participating candidates. U.S. Hillary Clinton Kirsten Gillibrand of New York sent a letter to lawmakers in her state Tuesday urging them to pass the marriage equality bill this year. Capitol Tonight reports on the letter, in which Kirsten Gillibrand wrote, Equal protection under the law has been a hallmark of the American legal, social and political system since the founding of the republic. In this instance, I believe that this principle must be extended to all of those in our state who seek the civil contract of marriage and the numerous legal rights, protections and benefits that only the status of marriage confers. The correspondence accompanied a lobby day in Albany sponsored by Marriage Equality New York, which drew around 300 participants, or more than double the number from last year.
